text:
Six days

The sea’s eerie silence is unlike any silence found on land — it rings like a haunting. The Revenge, motionless as she is, struggles under the weight of the crew’s misery. Her unfurled sails hang limply with no wind to billow them. The sun beats down on Ed’s bare shoulders like a punishment where he hangs in the starboard rigging, taking swigs of rum and counting clouds on the horizon. Even he gave up his leather jacket days ago and his skin has become taut, freckled, in-part burned by the unrelenting god-sun above them. 
Ed has survived his fair share of becalmings. He has survived thirst, sunstroke, starvation, torture, scurvy, and his father. The thick, gnarled scar on the left side of his belly throbs with every breath. He has dodged death, and madness, and the whipping winds of an unforgiving sea. 
Stede Bonnet steps out onto the deck below him, dressed down to his breeches and an undershirt, and squints against the sun to smile brightly at Ed hanging in the rigging. 
“Good morning, Ed!” he shouts, unwaveringly cheerful. 
“Morning, mate,” says Ed, tips his bottle, and finds his gaze stuck on the tender, pale line of Stede’s shoulder beneath the sheer white of his top. 
Ed has survived his fair share of becalmings. He has survived thirst, sunstroke, starvation, torture, scurvy, and his father. He isn't sure if he will survive Stede Bonnet. 
*** 
During the first three days of their unfortunate standstill, Stede had kept the crew busy with games, stories and maintenance jobs. Never before had the deck of the Revenge sparkled as it did then. Never before had its crew heard so many stories. On the fourth day, Lucius nearly died of sunstroke and the mood took a tumble so severe not even Stede could hope to fix it. 
They’re running low on fresh water. They were en route to Nassau for a restock when the wind stopped. Roach has taken to obsessively rationing what little rain water is left, checking the levels and reporting them to Stede like that is going to change anything. Stede, in turn, keeps Ed informed of the water levels, as though he expects him to be able to do something about it. 
On the third day, Stede swayed a little dangerously and said meekly that he felt dizzy from thirst, so now Ed threatens Roach to keep quiet as he tops up Stede’s water ration from his own in the early hours of every day. 
(“You’ll die of thirst,” Roach warns. 
“Fuck off,” Ed says. He’s built for this, Stede isn’t. “I’m fine.”) 
Since day two, there has been an undercurrent of dumb panic in the way Stede moves, a trill of hysterics in his voice. He knows that he can’t fix this with unrelenting goodwill. The wind will not respond to positive reinforcement and team-building exercises. 
This doesn’t deter Stede from trying. Every deliriously hot morning he gets the crew together for a brainstorming session in the shade, trying to problem-solve his way out of a becalming. 
“We could do a rain dance,” Frenchie suggests on that sixth morning. It isn't the first time it has been suggested but Stede nods vigorously anyways. 
“Brilliant. That’s great, Frenchie. Does anyone know any, er, rain dance routines?” 
Ed drops his head back and looks at the mast, standing stark against a blinding sky. 
“If it’s no’a full moon, don’t bother,” says Buttons. “She’ll only smite us.” Who  she  is, he doesn’t say. 
“That’s unfortunate. The full moon is a fortnight away,” Stede sighs, sounding miserable enough that Ed snaps his head over to check on him. 
He catches Stede’s eye and gets a smile in return, a sad tug of the lips. Ed wants to drape fine cashmere around his shoulders and hide him from the sun. This man isn’t made for thirst. This man should be drenched in clean water, his lips wet and pink, sweet coconut oil in his sun kissed hair. 
“No bother,” Stede says and claps his hands together, resolutely and forcefully upbeat. “We will organise a rain dance, with or without the moon. Gentlemen, I suggest you all come up with some elegant shimmies that will impress the gods. A rain dance extravaganza!” 
The Swede yelps in excitement and jumps to his feet with more vigour than anyone on the crew has shown in days. Lucius, still sickly pale from his brief stint on the deathbed, rolls his eyes. 
*** 
“Ed, I don’t know what to do.” Stede all but collapses on the chaise lounge. It’s hours past nightfall and the captain’s quarters have cooled to a bearable temperature, though the air is still stuffy. They always find themselves back here, at the end of each sweltering day. 
“Can't do anything but wait,” Ed says softly and sits down at an acceptable distance from Stede. “The wind will come back.” 
“And what if it doesn’t?” There it is, the trill of hysterics. Stede casts a wild look at the lighthouse painting on his mantle. He twists the ring on his index finger, the skin across his knuckles taut and white. “What if we die here? I can’t fail them.” 
"Hey." Ed reaches across because it's the only thing that feels right. He grasps Stede's wrist and smoothes the pad of his thumb across his knuckles. Stede stops fiddling with his ring and looks up at him, wide-eyed. "This isn't Captain shit. This is God shit. Are you God?" 
The room is blank with silence. 
Gently, Ed repeats, "Are you God, Stede?" 
Stede's voice is thin and high when he answers, "I'm not God." 
"And is God here, in this room?" 
Comically, Stede looks around like he might find God perched on the edge of his desk, or pulling books from his shelves to examine the spines. 
"He's not," Stede concedes. 
"That's right, mate. Stupid bugger doesn't associate himself with pirates." Ed smiles. "But the whole world needs the wind. It needs storms and rainfall just as much as the fucking sun. People are always praying for it. So the wind will come, and there's nothing we can do but wait." 
Stede turns his hand over in Ed's grasp and for a moment they're holding onto each other, right here in this godless room, but then Stede lets go. 
"You're a good friend, Ed," says Stede. "Thank you." 
Ed wants to howl. 
 

  Seven days  

That morning, early enough that the Revenge is still quiet with sleep, Ed looks up from polishing his pistol when the aft door opens and watches Stede step out onto the deck in just his breeches, his hair unkempt. No cravat, no flowing shirt, no buttons. No fucking buttons. He stares. Stede takes a deep lungful of breath and Ed is fixated on his chest, the fine dusting of hair, his collar bones, his nipples.
Then Stede spots him and breaks out into a surprised smile, but seems to remember himself and self-consciously crosses his arms over his chest. 
"Ed! Hello! Er, what are you doing here? So early!" He stutters through the words. "I was just— Don't let me distract you from... whatever it is you are doing. I meant to—" 
And before Ed can do anything but lift his hand to wave, Stede has rushed back under deck, leaving him and his pistol and his thoughts. 
Ed knows how to deal with lust, he really does. Decades spent at sea, you can't be shy about these things. You either bite the bullet and do something about it, or you drive yourself mad under all that sweat, that blood, and booze. He knows how to touch men. He knows how to fuck men and be fucked by them. But there is something about Stede Bonnet that reduces him to coveting awkward, quick touches, desperate for something but at once afraid of it. Because, he thinks privately, once he starts touching Stede he may never want to stop and that is a dangerous place to be. 
The metal of his pistol is cold and sleek where the bone of his wrist follows the rag he drags across it. In a few short hours, once the sun comes up above the waves, the air around him will be buzzing with heat again, and he will have to look Stede in the eye without his knees buckling. 
"Fuck off," he says to no one in particular, then gets to his feet. He should probably do something with the image of Stede's bare chest lingering on his tongue. 
***
When Stede nearly brains himself on the hull of the ship trying to step off the ladder and onto the dinghy, Ed reflexively reaches for him. He gets his arm around Stede's hip to steady him and instantly regrets it. 
"Careful, mate," he mutters while his body starves. 
Stede clings to Ed's arm until his feet are firmly in the dinghy. Only then does he untangle himself and put some distance between them. 
Ed squints at him, the sunlight high in his eyes. 
Primly, Stede says, "Thank you." Always polite. Then he gives a thumbs up in the direction of Frenchie and Oluwande poking their head over the railing to make sure their captain doesn't drown. 
"Alright," says Ed and pushes off the hull of the ship. Their dinghy rocks gently away from The Revenge. He picks up the harpoon propped up against the side of the boat, tied to the bench with a rope. "Let's catch some sharks."
"Sharks?" Stede squeaks. "But you said fish!" 
"Sharks are fish." He hoists the harpoon up on his shoulder. "C'mon, man, start rowing." 
"Oh God." 
Stede sits down on the bench and does as he's told while Ed watches for movement below the water's surface. 
"Have you ever caught a shark before?" Stede asks eventually, sounding uncertain. 
"Yep," Ed nods. "Plenty." 
"So... what's the proper technique?" 
"You stab 'em." 
"With the harpoon." 
"No, with a fucking pencil." 
Stede actually laughs. Ed's stomach does a funny little flip. He is lightheaded — from thirst and from heat. Perhaps from Stede fucking Bonnet. 
"Now that would be quite something," Stede says, amused. 
"Quite something," Ed hums. "Okay, stop here." 
Stede stops rowing and Ed stomps the heel of his boot on the floor. Stede makes a sound like someone dying. 
"The trick is to get it in the brain," Ed tells him. "Otherwise it'll swim on and drag us with it." 
He looks back at Stede and finds him grimacing. 
"Sounds... dangerous." 
"For the shark, yeah." 
"And for us." 
"Thought you wanted to be a better pirate. Hunting sharks is part of the advanced level pirate diploma." 
"Oh, is it?" Stede's voice is faint. "Well then. I'll watch and learn." 
Ed stomps his heel again. This time something bumps back. Stede squeaks. 
"Ed, are you sure this is— I mean, we still have some rations, maybe we don't need to, er, do this— We can just—" 
"Shh." Ed puts one finger to his lips and tightens his grip on the harpoon. "I'll take care of it." 
"Okay," Stede says softly. 
The dinghy rocks with the gentle ghost of a predator below. Ed, the predator above, leans forward on the tips of his toes and looks over the edge. The water is clear enough that he can see the grey body of his prey. An easy target. Should be. 
He waits for the shark to cross below the boat, and then he shouts and throws the harpoon with all the strength he can muster. He misses, but narrowly. 
"Did you get it?" Stede gasps and jumps up from his place on the bench. 
"Fuck!" Ed pulls the rope to get the harpoon back. "Missed." 
"Ah, that's a shame. I guess we'll have to go back to the ship, you know, to regroup and strategise." 
Ed drops the harpoon and it clatters to the floor. It's too fucking hot. The sun beats down on him like hellfire and he so desperately wants to jump into the water. Never mind the sharks, it would be a kinder death than being burned alive. 
He casts a look over his shoulder at Stede, who gives him one of those sweet little smiles, that lips-pressed-together, eyes-wide smile that makes Ed believe he could be a better person. 
"Alright, hold on," he grunts. "'m trying again." 
He grasps the hem of his t-shirt and pulls it over his head. Too fucking warm. He crumples it up and drops it. Then he picks the harpoon back up, readies it, and steadies one knee on the edge of the boat. 
"Er," Stede says behind him, sounding choked. "Okay." 
The shark circles below them, not spooked by Ed's previous attempt on its life. Sweat pools in the dips of Ed's collarbones. He waits. He waits. 
He stops. 
“Stede,” he says. “Come here. I’ll show you.” 
“Uh, oh. I’ll only be in your way, really. And what if we have to start rowing away quickly? It’s probably best if I sit here and… observe.” 
Ed turns to look at him, unimpressed. Stede is wide-eyed and staring at, must be, Ed’s chest. It’s intensely gratifying. 
“C’mon, mate. I need your help.” 
Stede gets up. The boat wobbles dangerously. Ed widens his stance to balance the weight. 
“Here,” Ed says and hands him the harpoon. 
“Christ.” Stede takes it in both hands, hesitant like it’s about to explode in his face. “And what do I do with it?” 
Ed takes Stede by the shoulders and guides him to the edge of the boat. His palms are flat against Stede’s shoulder blades. He stands behind him — only a few inches and his chest would be pressed against Stede's back. 
“Hold it up like so,” he instructs and nudges Stede’s elbow into a more natural position. “You have to be able to aim. Can’t do that with your elbow locked.” 
Stede exhales shakily. Says, “Mhm,” and grips the harpoon like his life depends on it, white-knuckled and trembling. 
“Look down,” Ed murmurs, and Stede does. 
“Oh God,” he gasps. “That’s a shark.” 
“It is, yeah. But this guy’s just a fish. You’ve got thumbs and a harpoon.” 
“I do have thumbs,” Stede concedes. “Take that, sharks!” 
“And a harpoon. So use it.” 
“How? I’m a terrible thrower.” 
Ed circles Stede with his arms and grasps his wrists lightly. It’s really too warm for fucking flirting. His head throbs, blood beating in his temples. But then Stede relaxes into him a fraction and Ed just wants to be  closer.  
He shows Stede the motion. Draws his hands back, the harpoon with it. 
“Aim the tip,” he says. “Hit the brain. C’mon, now. Shark’s gonna get out of here before you get your act together. Be a pirate, man.” 
He lets go of Stede’s wrists and takes a reluctant step back. 
“This is really very…” 
Then Stede pulls his arm back and launches the harpoon. It whips through the air and embeds itself in the flesh of the beast. The head, as he wanted. 
“Exciting,” Stede finishes. 
Ed whoops triumphantly and jumps into action, grabbing the rope and pulling it taut. The shark flops uselessly in the water, struggling, but does not have enough momentum to move away. 
"Fuckin’ hero,” Ed shouts. “Help me get this thing on board.” 
Together they yank and hook the shark, pulling it over the edge and into the dinghy. It struggles wildly until Ed gets his dagger in it. 
Only then does Stede look up from the beast to look at Ed. Still wide-eyed and surprised, but there is something burning there, too. 
When Ed smiles at him wildly, Stede laughs. 
“The crew are going to love you,” Ed says. 
“Us, you mean.” 
“Yeah. Us.” 
***
The crew does love them for it. Roach cooks the shark meat perfectly and distributes it evenly amongst the crew that night.
They sit and eat. The world seems more bearable with the sun down. Across the lantern light in between them, Ed looks at Stede. His face is touched gold by the flickering fire. 
When he sees him looking, Stede smiles and raises his shark skewer in a half-joking greeting. Ed ducks his head, unsure of what to do with himself. 
 Dear fucking God, man. He can’t go on like this. 
*** 
"Are you serious?" 
Lucius stares at him, his mouth agape. 
"Yes, I'm fucking serious, do I look like I'm joking? Do I look like a clown?" 
They're in the storage cupboard. Somewhere above them, Frenchie and the Swede sing shanties, out of tune but dedicated. 
"Have you tried to make a move at all?" Lucius' expression is pinched. "Anything? Surely you have moves."
Ed looks at him, unhappy. "Tried taking my shirt off in front of him."
Lucius sounds genuinely surprised when he asks, "And that didn't work?"
"The shark might have ruined the mood." 
"You made a move on him while trying to hunt for  sharks?" 
Ed raises his eyebrows at his tone. 
"You two deserve each other." 
"Fuck off," Ed snaps, secretly glowing with it. "I wouldn't ask if I had any other options."
"I think you have plenty of options," Lucius says, waggles his eyebrows, and Ed thinks that if he had enough hair he would be twirling it. "But I'll see what I can do." 
"You don't have to do anything," Ed snaps. "I don't want you to do anything. I want you to tell me what to do. I just need a nudge." 
"Nope," Lucius flutters his hand across Ed's shoulder like he is brushing imaginary dirt off his jacket. "You'll only fuck it up." 
Ed glowers at him. "Pushing it, boy." 
Lucius is still scared of him, he knows, but right now his love for shenanigans seems to outweigh any fear that may be lodged in his throat. 
"I know I am," says Lucius. "But I think Stede would be very disappointed if you stabbed me." 
And with that he does a mocking bow and exits the storage cupboard, leaving Ed inhaling dust all alone.  
 

  Eight days  

The thirst starts to get to Ed in the early afternoon. He crouches in the belly of the ship, away from the sun, and peers into his flask of carefully rationed water. There cannot be more than a few sips left. He knows, religiously, that if he went to Roach for more the man would give it to him, knows the way that people always relent to him — out of fear, or respect, or duty. It's precisely for that reason that he will not go to Roach. 
When he rises to full height he feels briefly lightheaded. His stomach roils. He steadies himself on a barrel and blinks away the fatigue. 
Things to do. Men to seduce. 
*** 
"Captain wants you," Lucius drawls, his head popping up from below deck. 
Ed's heart skips a beat and he pushes himself up on his elbows. They're lounging in the shadow of the main sail — Ed, Oluwande, Frenchie and Wee John. Ed had been here first and the others had sort of... congregated around him. He can’t quite place how that makes him feel. 
Lucius' shit-eating grin is enough to beat the flustered excitement out of him. 
"Where?" Ed grunts, unhappy. 
"His bathroom," Lucius says and disappears again. 
Ed's cheeks burn. Besides him, Oluwande looks at him like he has just realised something. 
 
He follows the corridor down to the captain's quarters, his nerves twinging with each step. He has been in Stede's bathroom before. Hell, he has cried in Stede's bathroom. But why would he be wanted there? 
Feeling like his skin is too tight, Ed stops outside the door. He raises his fist, hesitates, then raps his knuckles against the elegant wood three times. 
“Ah,” Stede’s voice comes muffled from inside. “Excellent! Come in!” 
Ed opens the door and its hinges squeak loudly. Stede is facing away from him, shirtless, and has his head bent over a bowl of some sorts. 
“Uh, hello?” Ed says, uncertain. He takes a few steps into the room but doesn’t come too close. From here he can see the ridges of Stede’s spine below taut, freckled skin. Ed clenches his fists by his side. 
“Er,” Stede says, head still bent. “Ed?” 
“Yeah?” 
Stede turns his head slowly and Ed can see his hair is dripping wet. Water splashes across the floor. 
“Always happy to see you, of course, but what are you doing here? Where’s Lucius?” 
Ed blinks in surprise. “Lucius— What? He told me—” 
The door slams shut behind him with a sudden bang. A metallic sound, like a key being turned in the lock. Ed whips around and tries the handle. The door doesn’t budge. 
He rattles the handle and shouts, “What the fuck?” 
On the other side of the door, Lucius shouts back, a tinge of hysterics to his voice, “This is your nudge! You can kill me later!” 
“C’mon, man, that’s fucked up!” 
“Yeah! But it’ll work! Sorry, bye!” Retreating footsteps, then a final door shutting. 
Behind him, Stede says, “You don’t happen to have a, uh, towel?” 
Ed turns to him slowly, resigned to his terrible, sweet fate of being stuck in a room with a shirtless Stede Bonnet. 
“No,” he replies. “Sorry, mate.” 
“Well, that’s just— Fab. I asked Lucius to fetch one for me.” 
“He fetched me instead.” 
“I did think he took an awfully long time. Any idea why? What’s the… nudge?” 
Ed leans against the door, as far away from Stede as he possibly can be in the small room. 
“It’s just a stupid joke. We’re playing—  It’s like a game? Where we do stupid shit.” It feels like digging his own grave. “He’s being an idiot. I’ll talk to him.” 
“If by talking you mean threatening him, please don’t. He nearly died just a few days ago. We run a gentle ship here.” 
“Yeah, sure, man. I’ll be nice.” 
For a moment, they stand in silence, Ed against the door and Stede with his head bent over the bowl. It becomes too much too quickly. 
“So what the fuck are you doing?” 
“I’m washing my hair.” 
“Right.” 
“It’s not… I’m not using fresh water. I wouldn’t use fresh water right now.” 
“Stede, I know,” Ed says quickly. “Of course you wouldn’t.” 
“Right, yes, I didn’t want you to think—” 
“No, mate, I wouldn’t think that.” 
Stede sighs. He squeezes his blond waves to wring the water out furtively.  “I really need a towel.” 
“You can use my shirt?” 
That has to be the lamest come-on in the history of piracy. Thinly-veiled, moronic, there is no way Stede will think he— 
“Oh, that’s…! That’s so very nice of you, but I wouldn’t want to rob you of your clothes!” 
Ed blinks. He expected to be called out on it, not to be taken at face-value. 
“It’s not an issue,” he says, utterly fond. “It’ll dry.” 
Stede chuckles, a nervous edge to it. “Ed, really.” 
“C’mon, mate.” Without any more fuss, he takes off his shirt. He looks down at the purple fabric, then at Stede’s naked back. “It’ll dry, won’t it?” 
He crosses the room in a few short strides and holds out the shirt to Stede, nudging his shoulder. Stede turns his head, face red from being upside down, his hair dripping and dark with water. 
“Hah, um,” Stede squeaks. “Thank you.” 
He reaches out to take the shirt and Ed watches as he expertly wraps it around his head in a little turban-like situation. It’s so overwhelmingly charming that it knocks the breath out of Ed’s lungs. 
“There you go,” he says, strained. 
Stede straightens up and there it is again, that thin-lipped, wide-eyed smile. With his hair wrapped up, he looks even more naked than before. 
Ed takes a step back out of some long buried self-preservation instinct. He is suddenly and acutely aware of the fact that they are both shirtless and locked in a bathroom. Stede seems to be going through a similar process, and his sweet smile grows increasingly tight. 
“So what’s this game you’re playing with Lucius then?” Stede asks and begins massaging his scalp through Ed’s t-shirt, which has turned dark with water. 
“Um, nothing, it’s… Stupid, you wouldn’t want to be involved.” 
“No, come on, I love stupid games. What are the rules?” 
“No rules, just… It’s not even really a game, if you break it down,” Ed stammers and takes another nervous step backwards. He looks around for something to occupy him. Anything. He settles on a pot of what seems to be some kind of fancy-schmancy bathroom product, which he picks up and unscrews. He sticks his nose in it and it smells of rosemary and bergamot. 
“How does locking you in a bathroom come into it?” 
“It’s about… mental perseverance. And, um, problem solving.” 
“Ooh, I love that. Sounds challenging.” He pauses. “So how do you get him to unlock the door? Is there a trick?” 
“Might have to break the door down,” Ed says and sets the rosemary and bergamot thing back down on the side. He picks up a bottle, some sort of oil. Sniffs it. Coconut and something citrus-adjacent. 
Stede says, “I’d rather you didn’t,” and Ed immediately puts the oil down and looks at him, uncertain. 
“No, you can have the oil, I meant the door. I’d rather you didn’t break down my door. I’m quite fond of it. Surely there’s another way to win this game?” While he speaks, Stede unwraps his make-shift headpiece and folds the damp t-shirt neatly. He hangs it over the edge of the bathtub. “Could you pass me that oil, please?” 
Ed hands it to him. He watches him pour some into his cupped hand, then spread it evenly by rubbing his palms together. 
“Is that for your hair?” he asks, captivated. 
“Mhm, yes.” Stede looks over at him with a slight smile and begins running his hands through his hair. He combs his fingers through the damp strands carefully, methodically, like he does this all the time. And he must, for his hair to be so shiny and coiffed no matter the situation.
“Smells nice,” Ed says, without meaning to. “The oil. And you, usually.” 
Stede scrunches up his nose in embarrassment. “Oh, that’s— That’s nice to hear. You smell good, too.” 
“You don’t have to say that,” Ed says, amused. He knows he smells like stale sweat and old leather and sea salt. Sometimes, these days, he smells like Stede’s lavender soap but that never lasts more than a few hours. 
Stede’s hands come away from his hair shiny with oil. Ed wishes he would run them through his beard, so he can breathe in the scent, feel Stede’s fingers on his jaw. 
“I’m not just being polite, you smell nice!” he insists. 
“I don’t bathe enough to smell nice,” Ed says and sits down on the edge of the dresser holding Stede’s fancy oils and creams. “You bathe an appropriate amount.” 
“Well, you’re welcome to the tub any time.” 
“Am I?” 
Stede turns to rinse the oil off his hands in his little bowl of soapy water. With his back turned he says, “Yes, of course. Anytime.” 
Ed hums. “Maybe I will, when we’re back in the wind.” 
“You should. I’ll ask Roach to boil water for you. Nothing like a hot bath on a stormy day.” 
“Can’t imagine anything worse than a hot bath right now.” 
Stede laughs, “It’s stupidly warm, isn’t it?” 
“Yes,” Ed sighs, empathetic. “Thought I might die of thirst earlier.” 
“Oh, Ed, you should have said. I can spare some of my water,” Stede says and he sounds genuinely concerned. He turns to look at him and wipes his wet hands on his breeches, which Ed thinks is positively obscene of him. “Are you okay? Are you feeling well?” 
“It’s fine,” he chokes. He digs his nails into the wood of the dresser. “I’m good. Keep your water.”  Keep mine too. 
Stede looks at him intently and Ed lets himself look back. They are both perfectly still. 
Finally, Stede says, “Tell me about this game.” 
“It’s stupid.” 
“Can’t be worse than letting Calico Jack whip your…” He nearly chokes on it. “Privates.” 
Ed has to laugh. “Hm, yeah, it’s not that stupid.” 
“What are the rules?” 
“The rules are,” Ed starts. “Lucius locks us in a room until I come on to you. If I don’t, I lose.” 
He watches Stede’s throat work as he swallows. Wants to put his mouth all over him. Wants to do a lot of things, most of them filthy.
Stede’s voice is high-pitched when he asks, “And what if you do?” 
Ed’s blood pounds in his ears. “Then I get to come on to you.” 
“And you win?” 
“Depends.” 
“On what?” 
“How you feel about me coming on to you.” 
Stede clasps his hands in front of his body like a nervous schoolboy. “Ah,” he says. “I reckon I would, er, feel quite good about that, perhaps. If you were to… do… that. What you said you might do. For the game.” 
“You would?” Ed can feel his heartbeat at the back of his throat. 
“Mhm,” Stede hums and he never once looks away, even when Ed takes a step forward, even when Ed reaches out to graze his fingertips along his collarbone. 
He doesn’t know how to do this. He doesn’t know how to be tender and touch softly, but by God does he want to. He fucking wants to. He wants to hold Stede’s heart in the palm of his hand, the same way Stede folded his and tucked it into his breast pocket with all the gentleness of a lover.
